Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: The Digital Resource Impact, Validation and Evolution (DRIVE) Project

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Internet-accessible Digital Resources (DR) created by the bioinformatics community for storage and analysis of data (i.e., downloadable software, web servers and online databases -- also called "digital products") are an integral part of modern scientific research, innovation and productivity. The impact of DRs on science is indisputable -- a publication describing the development of a DR was among the annual top 3 most cited scientific publications seven times during the past twelve years. But despite the increasing rate by which DRs are being created, we and others have found that they tend to become inaccessible (i.e., "decay") in a time-dependent manner. DRs are so central to modern data analysis and scientific productivity that it is important to better understand what factors correlate with decay, maintenance, further development and utilization/adoption by the scientific community. This project will develop methods to define competitive niches for DRs by which they can then be categorized, compared and contrasted with similar DRs over time, and will identify factors that correlate with DR success and decay as well as approximate the impact of DR loss on scientific research and the scientific record.

DR decay represents not just a loss of scientific resources in terms of the time, expertise and money it cost to develop them, but also a potential threat to the reproducibility of studies that used them. This project will help to understand this issue from several perspectives by putting DRs within a historical context and identifying factors that correlate with DR success and failure. The results of this research will improve scientific understanding of the impact, use, stability and evolution of DRs and lay the groundwork to help understand how incentives for academic researchers to develop DRs correlate with the eventual outcome of the DR.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Previous studies have found that URLs decay in a time-dependent manner. Many of these URLs link to programs or web servers that serve as Scientific Data Analysis Resources (SDARs), which have had a major impact on science. Within MEDLINE, over the past two decades, 25% of the top 20 most cited papers were SDARs. Thus, the loss of SDARs could potentially be extremely disruptive to science. This project sought to examine additional factors that correlated with an SDARs continued availability online, and to estimate whether or not highly cited SDARs have a different rate of decay.

We conducted the largest URL decay study to date, encompassing over 27,000 unique URLs published in MEDLINE up to June 2015. We sent each to have its static content archived in both WebCite and Internet Archive, preserving at least their non-dynamic content for future generations. We found 3.4% of URLs had spelling/formatting errors, suggesting that an automated check for availability at the time of publication would be beneficial. Unsurprisingly, we found URLs continue to decay at the same rate as the earlier surveys first estimated, but it was interesting to see that the rate of decay was the same for all categories (see Figure). We found that URLs linking to SDARs tended to be more stable when there were more authors per paper, suggesting that when more people have been involved in creating an SDAR, there are more people vested in its continued availability. We hypothesized that experienced SDAR creators (senior authors that had published 5 or more papers describing the creation of an SDAR) would tend to have more of their SDARs available relative to inexperienced creators (only 1 SDAR published), but only a weak non-statistically significant difference was found (p=0.09). Finally, we found that SDAR creation is widely dispersed among institutions relative to scientific papers in general, which tend to disproportionately be produced by large institutions. This suggests a lower barrier to entry in terms of resources required to create an SDAR.

We crowdsourced the classification of these URLs into SDARs (54% of URLs), databases (19% of URLs) and other (27%) (e.g., links to videos/material) based on the surrounding context within each abstract they were first published in. We then compiled citation data for each URL. We used the Internet Archive to estimate the death date of each URL so that we could calculate the average number of citations per year during the lifetime of the URL. We found that the average number of citations correlated strongly with the probability the SDAR was still accessible (Figure). Training a logistic regression model to predict the probability of SDAR availability, conditioning out the effects of time, we find that citations are an extremely strong predictor of continued SDAR availability (Figure). This is an important finding, as it confirms the hypothesis that use of an SDAR by the scientific community serves as motivation for its continued availability online, and that the SDARs that decay are disproportionately the ones that are less cited (and likely less utilized) by the scientific community.

In summary, we found that sociological factors (# citations and # of authors to a lesser degree) affect the probability that SDARs will remain accessible online. We have archived the URLs we analyzed to preserve their static content for future generations. And we have found that SDARs have had a disproportionate impact on science, yet tend to be published in lower impact journals.


Last Modified: 03/17/2016
Modified by: Jonathan D Wren

Many of these URLs link to programs or web servers that serve as Scientific Data Analysis Resources (SDARs), which have had a major impact on science. Within MEDLINE, over the past two decades, 25% of the top 20 most cited papers were SDARs. Thus, the loss of SDARs could potentially be extremely disruptive to science.
